Quantum theory is a highly successful and elegant theory of nature. It is also a theory that is difficult to formalize mathematically. This is partly because it is a theory that is based on a set of axioms that are not analytical in nature. In this paper, we provide a set of axioms that guarantee a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is analytical in nature.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Less)

COVID-19 is a serious global health problem that has caused more than 50 million cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this disease, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to block the action of the host immune system by inhibiting the interferon (IFN) response. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the nuclear pore complex (NPC) to block the nuclear import of the transcription factors STAT1 and STAT2, which are central players in the IFN response. Our findings provide a molecular understanding of the viral strategy to overcome the IFN response and contribute to the development of new antiviral strategies. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of the proton channel. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits the proton channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the proton channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize yields and yields variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase substantially in all major maize-producing countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in all major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for increased investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

Herbivores are a major component of global biodiversity, and the number of species of herbivore is often greater than that of plants. This high diversity is thought to be a consequence of the ability of herbivores to partition food resources, but the extent to which they do so is unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of herbivores in shaping plant communities and the biodiversity they contain. It also provides a model for the application of DNA metabarcoding to the study of diet in other taxa.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is a key determinant of business survival. Businesses with longer projections of the crisis are more likely to remain open. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the elements. The solar system is also the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the elements in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to the mother during pregnancy is a strong predictor of reproductive output. We also show that the degree of maternal care is a strong predictor of the amount of resources that can be provided. This suggests that the ability to provide resources to the mother is a strong predictor of reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA patients. The results also suggest that VX-765 could be used as a therapeutic strategy in other synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the most numerous cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, control blood pressure, and control inflammation. The endothelium is able to do this by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate information and control its functions. The endothelium is found to use a network of cells to communicate with each other. The network is found to be highly connected and to have a small-world configuration. The small-world configuration is found to be effective for both local and global communication. The findings have implications for our understanding of the endothelium and its role in the cardiovascular system. They also have implications for the design of networks in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, and the need for data-driven decision-making has never been greater. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide a resource for data-driven decision-making in the United States. The API provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a structural basis for the functional coupling of the selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant. Finally, it provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms that are essential for the health of the animal. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are likely to be important in the regulation of the microbiome. This study provides a catalog of the natural products produced by anaerobic fungi, which are a group of fungi that are likely to be important in the regulation of the gut microbiome. The results of this study provide a foundation for the discovery of novel natural products from anaerobic fungi.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. It is established by a hierarchy of individuals in a group, with the most dominant individual being the one that is most likely to be rewarded with access to the most rewarding resources. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to be associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens in the development of a subordinate status and show that this is a potential avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures that are composed of multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The proposed strategy can also be extended to design structures with complex and programmable responses. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses. It is expected to be widely applicable to a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is highly variable and is influenced by a variety of factors, including age, sex, and genetic background. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 is a downstream element of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway and is expressed at higher levels in fetal tissues. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 mediates the loss of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern and the gain of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobin disorders and for the control of hemoglobin expression in health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the survival rate of patients with cancer remains low. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis, which is a mechanism that protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptosis. Thus, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major public health issue. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are effective, but they have several side effects, including the development of heart failure. Our study shows that the major drugs of this class act on the Ca2+ signaling machinery and promote vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and provided a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. We show that the policy was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but not early-seral–associated species. The policy failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the creation of early-seral ecosystems has not been sufficient to reverse declines. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to design new antibiotics for other pathogens. It can also be extended to other problems in drug discovery. The approach is general and can be applied to other drug properties. It can also be extended to other problems in drug discovery.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices suppresses melatonin secretion, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These effects may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the boundary. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of terrestrial origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. This is accompanied by a shift in the balance between Treg cells and Th17 cells, and a change in the pattern of autoantibodies.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other viruses that cause diseases in humans.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is the strongest risk allele, and APOE2 is the strongest protective allele. APOE is also a major protein in the classical complement cascade, which is known to be involved in AD pathology. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that produces APOE.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the core and the evolution of the planet. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we propose a two-step nucleation mechanism of the inner core. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the most stable phase of iron at high pressure and temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron, which is the stable phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new approach to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is the only known organ with the capacity to produce language. Despite this, the brain’s neural mechanisms for language are poorly understood. Here, we use a new approach to link the brain’s activity to the computation that generates it. We find that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict neural responses in the human brain to sentences with 90% accuracy. These models’ fits to the data are also correlated with how well they predict the next word in a sentence. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension. They also suggest that the human brain may be more similar to a modern computer than we realized.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether DL is a general-purpose technology or just a black box that can be used for any problem. We show that the latter is the case, at least in some limited settings. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. These results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results suggest that the stability of the network is a key factor in the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of the population to comply with the necessary restrictions. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published 45 years ago. It is often claimed that the study’s results show that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This article discusses the study’s critical design flaws and shows that they are a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which have been shown to cause different forms of the disease. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with the most severe form of the disease. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the ancestral species than is M. leprae, and that they have retained similar sets of genes. This suggests that they are still capable of causing disease, and that the differences between them are the result of natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. Although the unitary time evolution ensuing from a pure state maintains the system at zero entropy, local properties at long times are captured by a statistical ensemble with nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the entanglement accumulated during the dynamics. Therefore, understanding the entanglement evolution unveils how thermodynamics emerges in isolated systems. Alas, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We thoroughly check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 500,000 deaths in the United States alone. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which may be difficult to achieve in the general population. Here, we describe a vaccine that is easy to manufacture, requires only one dose, and is highly protective. This vaccine is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that has been recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. This vaccine is highly attenuated, generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies, and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, this hypothesis is based on a lack of evidence rather than on a sound epidemiological model. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This model can be used to study the history of plague in Europe and to understand the spread of the disease in the past. It can also be used to study the spread of the disease in the present and the future.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience and a key parameter in many studies of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain numbers has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain capacity. We show that the evolution of brain capacity is also determined by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study also shows that the evolution of brain capacity is not only driven by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.
The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator, and that its expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers.

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the substrate for many cellular processes, including cell migration. Actin filaments are dynamic polymers, and they can be disassembled and reassembled by proteins that bind to them. These proteins are called actin depolymerizing factors (ADF). ADF proteins are members of the cofilin family, and they are named after cofilin, the best-characterized member of the family. Here, we show that cofilin binds to actin filaments and disassembles them, but the binding is reversible. We also show that cofilin can sever actin filaments, and we propose a mechanochemical mechanism that explains how this happens. This mechanism is important for cells, because it allows them to disassemble and reassemble actin filaments in a controlled manner.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the island was settled by a population that was already admixed. The settlement was not homogeneous across the island, suggesting that the settlement was not a single event but rather a series of independent events. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a framework for the study of the human history of the Indian Ocean. We live in a social world, and our emotions are influenced by the emotions of others. This is well established in the laboratory, where people are exposed to emotional stimuli and their emotions change. However, the extent to which this occurs in the real world is less clear. In this work, we show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in the real world, using a large social network dataset. This work suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, and that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, people can be influenced by the emotions of others without experiencing the emotions themselves. This work has implications for our understanding of social psychology, and for the design of social networks.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences are modified posttranscriptionally to regulate the rate of protein synthesis. One of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), is found in coding regions of mRNA. We report here that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the products of translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the products of translation.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in the hospital setting, and is also responsible for severe infections in the community. The bacterium is able to cause severe infections by producing a wide range of virulence factors, including toxins, proteases, and exotoxins. Here we show that the bacterium is able to sense the mechanical activity of its pili, which are used for twitching motility and biofilm formation. This mechanochemical sensing system is used by the bacterium to regulate its virulence.

The global use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing, and the number of pesticides is growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, including the presence of pesticides in surface water, the stringency of environmental regulations, and the effects of pesticides on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This study is of great importance for the global community, as it provides a comprehensive overview of the global pesticide situation and the effects of pesticides on aquatic biodiversity.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been documented in a variety of animal species, including dogs, cats, and ferrets. However, the role of animals in the spread of the virus is not fully understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern in North America. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study also provides a model for the surveillance of zoonotic viruses in wildlife. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that are being created, and the solutions that are needed. We propose that the industry needs to move away from building large dams and toward smaller hydropower dams, which are more appropriate for the developing world.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, but the earliest stages of the disease are poorly understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response. This finding has implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. Our results suggest that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by the Southern Levant by at least a century. This is an important step in the understanding of the spread of this species across the Mediterranean world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct steps are involved. This work shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps. The folding is fast, but the steps are slow. The folding is also heterogeneous, with different segments of the protein folding at different rates. The folding is also not a simple process of unfolding followed by folding. Instead, the folding is a process of unfolding followed by refolding. These results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA transcripts. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is normally responsible for ApaH inactivation, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme. This enzyme prefers Np4-capped RNA as substrates over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing immunosuppression. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for assessing the impact of human activities on the global biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics. It is characterized by the fact that a system, which is in a metastable state, can evolve to a critical state without any external intervention. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new drugs. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are derived from the legume plant Medicago truncatula. These peptides are highly diverse in sequence, and some of these cationic peptides exhibit antifungal activity in vitro and in vivo. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. We report the structure of one of the peptides, which is largely disordered and highly dynamic. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this class of peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and that the extent of female contributions is dependent on the duration of storage. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and the public interested in the origin of life.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to the receptor−ligand complex switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the switch is a general mechanism for regulating receptor−ligand interactions. The results are important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD and for understanding the regulation of receptor−ligand interactions. They also suggest that the switch is a general mechanism for regulating receptor−ligand interactions.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, viruses, fungi, and other microbes that are intimately associated with human health. The human virome, the set of viruses that are associated with the human body, is a largely unexplored component of the microbiome. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future research. The results of this study are also a significant contribution to the field of virology.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability of ACI is inadequate. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The HSRL is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spectral resolution, which is not available in current remote-sensing techniques. The HSRL was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The results show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The HSRL is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This article is the first of a series of articles to be published in this journal.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth, and it is also important for understanding the origin of life. This study presents a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important for normal physiology and pathophysiology. The K+ channel, BK, is a major regulator of the resting membrane potential of the heart and is also involved in arrhythmia. The BK channel is unique in that it has no classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channel function. It also provides a possible explanation for the BK channel’s unique properties and may have implications for the development of drugs for arrhythmia. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion, rather than the parasite using a single mechanism to invade. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza in the future.
